new_statement:
POLYNOMIAL IDENTIFICATION AND NOTATION (by_definition). DEPENDS ON: Node 1.1.

DOMAIN. The algebraic identities (items 1-5 below) hold over the polynomial ring Z[q,t,x_1,...,x_n]. The probabilistic interpretation (item 6) requires t in (0,1) and x_i > 0 for all i.

REFERENCES. We adopt the notation of BDW25 (arXiv:2510.02587) throughout. Cross-paper notation correspondences are given below.

NOTATION TABLE (BDW25 / AMW24 / CMW22):
- E*_lambda: nonsymmetric interpolation Macdonald polynomial, characterized by vanishing conditions (KS96; BDW25 Thm 2.3). E*_mu is the unique polynomial of degree d = |mu| with leading coefficient [x^mu]E*_mu = 1 and E*_mu(nu~) = 0 for nu != mu with |nu| <= d.
- f*_mu (BDW25 Def 1.2): interpolation ASEP polynomial (algebraic), defined by f*_mu := T_{sigma_mu} E*_lambda, where T_{sigma_mu} is a product of Hecke generators. This is an INHOMOGENEOUS polynomial (has lower-degree terms).
- F*_mu (BDW25 Def 1.14): interpolation ASEP polynomial (combinatorial), defined as a signed multiline queue weight-generating function.
- f*_mu = F*_mu: BDW25 Theorem 1.15 (nontrivial equality of the algebraic and combinatorial definitions).
- f_mu (BDW25) = F_eta (AMW24) = f_w (CMW22): homogeneous ASEP polynomial, defined as the top-degree homogeneous component of f*_mu (BDW25 Thm 2.3). WARNING: f_mu != f*_mu in general; f*_mu contains lower-degree correction terms.
- P*_lambda (BDW25 Prop 2.15): interpolation Macdonald polynomial, satisfying P*_lambda = sum_{mu in S_n(lambda)} f*_mu.
- P_lambda (all papers): symmetric Macdonald polynomial, satisfying P_lambda = sum_{mu in S_n(lambda)} f_mu. For INTERPOLATION polynomials this is BDW25 Prop 2.15; for HOMOGENEOUS polynomials this follows by extracting the top-degree component of both sides.

CLAIMS:
(1) f*_mu := T_{sigma_mu} E*_lambda (BDW25 Definition 1.2).
(2) f*_mu = F*_mu (BDW25 Theorem 1.15).
(3) f_mu := top-degree homogeneous component of f*_mu (BDW25 Theorem 2.3).
(4) P*_lambda = sum_{mu in S_n(lambda)} f*_mu (BDW25 Proposition 2.15).
(5) P_lambda = sum_{mu in S_n(lambda)} f_mu (follows from (4) by extracting top-degree parts; also AMW24 arXiv:2403.10485, Theorem 1.1).
(6) At q=1, for t in (0,1), x_i > 0: the f_mu(x;q=1,t) (equivalently F_eta in AMW24 notation) are stationary weights of the inhomogeneous multispecies t-PushTASEP on S_n(lambda), with P_lambda(x;q=1,t) as partition function (AMW24 arXiv:2403.10485, Theorem 1.1).

NOTE: The bridge from interpolation ratios f*_mu/P*_lambda to homogeneous ratios f_mu/P_lambda is NOT established in this node; it is deferred to Node 1.6.
